The article attached below is written by Cherian George, a Singaporean political analyst and historian.

Quote from article: "By relying more on internal checks by good men than external scrutiny by a fearless press, parliamentary opposition and civil society, LKY was brushing aside key institutions we know are required to build and preserve a system with integrity." (Note: LKY == Lee Kuan Yew)

My take is that in Singapore, Parliamentary opposition and civil society have been found to be very poor institutions at holding the ruling party in check. In fact, intense scrutiny has been placed on  Parliamentary opposition in Singapore, for instance the AHPETC saga and COI into Raeesah Khan's conduct. Furthermore, I personally have little faith in the press at holding public servants to scrutiny. The press is populist, serves the whims of the masses, and appeals to the lowest common denominator.

Please organize my above opinions into a more articulate and nuanced response

---


WHAT LKY SAW, AND DIDN'T

The Nassim Jade controversy of 1996 is interesting to revisit not only because it, too, starred a certain Ong Beng Seng, but also because it happened during a transformational period in PAP governance.

Starting out leftist, the PAP had very quickly acknowledged the need to ride the waves of global capitalism, courting multinationals with a vengeance. Culturally, however, the PAP leaders remained austere, and suspicious of local business elites. 

By the 1990s, Lee realised that the government’s ambitions to develop an external wing to the Singapore economy required consorting with these capitalists. He acknowledged that this rubbed against the PAP grain. He told Parliament during the Nassim Jade debate: 

“Our problem now is we are going regional in a big way. So I have had Ministers telling me, ‘Better don't meet these people.’ I have never met these people before. But to go regional, I have met Ng Teng Fong, I have met the Kwek brothers, Kwek Leng Joo, I have met Ong Beng Seng."

He added: “Dr Aline Wong [then a Senior Minister of State] is very wise, she told my brother, Dr Lee Suan Yew, who told me recently, this is all very dangerous, giving these people face and stature in Singapore. My being seen with them. But there is no way. How can I help them go regional into China or Vietnam, unless I know how they operate, what are their problems, what can I do to clear these road blocks? I have met them privately in my office to discuss these problems.”

Lee shared his immediate reaction when he first realised that Ong’s company had given him a 7% discount and his son Lee Hsien Loong a 12% discount for their property purchases. “[M]y first thought was: ‘This man, Ong Beng Seng, is a dangerous fellow. He is investing in the young man and not investing in the old!’” Lee, I think, was wryly noting that Ong seemed to be grooming the younger Lee. “So I told him, when I saw him on Thursday evening, ‘Look, don't fool around. I look at it, I think you are up to no good. You say you are not up to no good, you explain.’”

Lee’s speech shows him to have been extremely conscious of the risks of what economists call state capture by corporate titans. His response was classic LKY — put faith in internal discipline, guided by the ethos of good men. “I can eat with Ong Beng Seng and Koh Beng Seng and I would still be the same person. No difference. And that is again back to character and a code of honour.”

I think any political scientist today, and historians of Singapore politics in the future, will recognise the great flaw in his strategy. By relying more on internal checks by good men than external scrutiny by a fearless press, parliamentary opposition and civil society, LKY was brushing aside key institutions we know are required to build and preserve a system with integrity. 

In theory, we could and should have both: robust internal and external checks. In practice, however, the PAP has insisted that good men with the right ethos will only come forward if society and the press go easy on them. This is one of the PAP's rationalisations for the suppression of freedom of expression. 
There is truth to the observation that a toxic political environment will deter good people from coming forward. But a system designed to protect good rulers from the rabble also gives imperfect men a sense of impunity and delays the timely exposure of questionable conduct. Citizens will have to decide which, in today's Singapore, poses the bigger risk.

Your response could be structured as follows to reflect a more articulate and nuanced perspective:

---

While Cherian George argues that Lee Kuan Yew (LKY) placed too much faith in internal checks by "good men" at the expense of external scrutiny by the press, parliamentary opposition, and civil society, I find myself skeptical of the role that these institutions have played, particularly in Singapore’s context. Parliamentary opposition and civil society have, in my view, proven to be ineffective at holding the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) accountable. Instead of acting as reliable checks, these institutions have often been targets of intense scrutiny themselves, diverting attention away from their intended role.

Take, for instance, the Aljunied-Hougang-Punggol East Town Council (AHPETC) saga or the Committee of Inquiry (COI) into Raeesah Khan's conduct—both of which involved significant public focus on opposition members. These episodes highlight how parliamentary opposition is often put under a microscope in ways that stifle its ability to function as a meaningful counterbalance to the ruling party. Similarly, civil society organizations, despite their role in democratic accountability, have struggled to gain enough traction to be an effective force in this regard.

As for the press, I hold little faith in its capacity to scrutinize public servants effectively. Media outlets tend to cater to popular sentiment, often prioritizing content that appeals to the masses rather than rigorously holding those in power accountable. In many cases, the press panders to populist tendencies, operating at the lowest common denominator to drive engagement, leaving little room for substantial critique or investigation.

In this light, while I agree with George that LKY may have over-relied on internal mechanisms of integrity, I am not convinced that external checks—specifically parliamentary opposition, civil society, and the press—have proven themselves to be viable or dependable in Singapore. These institutions, while critical in theory, have not lived up to their democratic potential here.

This leaves citizens with a complex dilemma: should we push for external checks that have historically been ineffective in Singapore, or should we continue to refine internal checks and balances within the PAP's governance framework? Neither approach is without flaws, but given the current political environment, perhaps the focus should be on strengthening the internal ethos and transparency mechanisms within the ruling system, rather than solely relying on external actors that have yet to fully rise to the occasion.

Here’s a more informal version of your response:

---

While it’s mostly true that LKY placed too much trust in internal checks by "good men" rather than external scrutiny by the press, parliamentary opposition, and civil society, I can’t help but feel skeptical about how well these external institutions have worked in Singapore’s context. Parliamentary opposition and civil society, in my opinion, haven’t done much to hold the PAP accountable. Instead of acting as reliable checks, they often end up being the ones under intense scrutiny themselves, which takes attention away from their actual purpose.

Look at the AHPETC saga or the COI into Raeesah Khan’s conduct—both put the opposition in the spotlight in ways that really undermine their ability to act as a true counterbalance to the ruling party. Civil society, despite its role in accountability, hasn’t gained enough traction to be a serious force either.

When it comes to the press, I don’t have much faith in its ability to effectively scrutinize public servants. A lot of the time, the media seems more interested in catering to popular sentiment, prioritizing content that appeals to the masses rather than critically holding power to account. It often feels like the press panders to populism, aiming for clicks or engagement, leaving little room for serious investigation or critique.

So while I agree with you that LKY may have over-relied on internal mechanisms of integrity, I’m not entirely convinced that external checks—especially parliamentary opposition, civil society, and the press—have proven to be reliable or effective in Singapore. These institutions, while important in theory, just haven’t lived up to their potential here.

This leaves us with a tough question: should we keep pushing for external checks that haven’t historically worked in Singapore, or should we focus on refining internal checks and balances within the PAP’s framework? Both approaches have their flaws, but given the current climate, it might make more sense to work on strengthening internal transparency and ethics within the ruling system, rather than relying too much on external actors that haven’t quite risen to the occasion yet.
